Biomedicine – also referred to as “conventional medicine” according to the biomedical
96
model, is a branch of medical science that applies biological and physiological
97
principles to clinical practice (1). Biomedicine emphasizes standardized, evidence98
based treatment validated through biological research, with treatment administered via
99
formally trained doctors, nurses, and other licensed practitioners.
100
Complementary medicine – used interchangeably for “traditional medicine” in some
101
countries, refers to a broad set of health care knowledge, skills and practices that are
102
not typically part of a country’s established traditional or conventional medicine, and
103
may play a supportive role in conjunction with biomedical care.
104
Digital health – the field of knowledge and practice associated with the development
105
and use of digital technologies to improve health. Digital health expands the concept
106
of eHealth to include digital consumers, with a wider range of smart and connected
107
devices. It also encompasses other uses of digital technologies for health such as the
108
Internet of Things, advanced computing, big data analytics, and artificial intelligence,
109
including machine learning and robotics (2).
110
Drug/medicine – any substance or pharmaceutical product for human or veterinary
111
use that is intended to modify or explore physiological systems or pathological states
112
for the benefit of the recipient (2).
113
Health practitioner – any health worker who has acquired health-related qualifications.
114
It comprises both health professionals and health associate professionals (4).
115
Herbal medicines – may include herbs, herbal materials, herbal preparations and
116
finished herbal products in a form suitable for administration to humans (5).
117
Herbal product – broad term encompassing herbal medicines and related products
118
(6).
119
Indigenous knowledge – the understandings, skills and philosophies developed by
120
societies with long histories of interaction with their natural surroundings. For rural and
121
indigenous peoples, local knowledge informs decision-making about fundamental
122
aspects of day-to-day life (7).
123
Indigenous traditional medicine – is defined as the sum of knowledge and practices,
124
whether explicable or not, used in diagnosing, preventing or eliminating physical,
125
mental and social diseases. This knowledge or practice may rely exclusively on
126
experience and observation handed down orally or in writing from generation to
127
generation. These practices are native to the country in which they are practised. Most
128
indigenous traditional medicine has been practised at the primary health care level (8).
129
Indigenous health practitioner – any health practitioner whose practice is rooted in
130
his/her indigenous knowledge and practice.
131
Integrative medicine – is an interdisciplinary and evidence-informed approach aimed
132
at achieving whole-person health and well-being by using a respectful combination or
133
fusion of biomedical and traditional and/or complementary medical knowledge, skills
134
and practices. It provides holistic care spanning the care continuum and may involve
135
various health care providers and institutions (9).

One Health – is an integrated, unifying approach that aims to sustainably balance and
137
optimize the health of humans, animals, plants and ecosystems. It recognizes that the
138
health of humans, domestic and wild animals, plants and the wider environment
139
(including ecosystems) are closely linked and interdependent. The approach mobilizes
140
multiple sectors, disciplines and communities at varying levels of society to work
141
together to foster well-being and tackle threats to health and ecosystems, while
142
addressing the collective need for clean water, energy and air, safe and nutritional food,
143
taking action on climate change, and contributing to sustainable development (10).
144
People-centred care – an approach to care that consciously adopts the perspectives
145
of individuals, carers, families and communities and sees them as participants in and
146
beneficiaries of trusted health systems that respond to their needs and preferences in
147
humane and holistic ways. People-centred care also requires that people have the
148
education and support they need to make decisions and participate in their own care.
149
It is organized around the health needs and expectations of people rather than
150
diseases (11).
151
Person-centred care – care approaches and practices that see the person as a whole
152
with many levels of needs and goals, with these needs coming from their own personal
153
social determinants of health (11).
154
Primary care – a key process in the health system that supports first-contact,
155
accessible, continued, comprehensive and coordinated patient-focused care (12).
156
Primary health care – is a whole-of-society approach to health that aims at ensuring
157
the highest possible level of health and well-being and their equitable distribution by
158
focusing on people’s needs as early as possible along the continuum, ranging from
159
health promotion and disease prevention to treatment, rehabilitation and palliative care,
160
and as close as feasible to people’s everyday environment (12).
161
Traditional, complementary and integrative medicine health product – may
162
include products of various classifications generally used as medicines or for health
163
purposes including, but not limited to “botanical medicines”, “complementary
164
medicines”, “dietary supplements”, “food supplements”, “health supplements”, “herbal
165
medicinal products”, “herbal medicines”, “herbal products”, “natural health products”,
166
or “traditional medicines” (13). It also includes any other health technologies and
167
devices originating from or specific to traditional, complementary and integrative
168
medicine.
169
Traditional, complementary and integrative medicine health practitioner – any
170
health worker who has acquired qualifications with regards to traditional,
171
complementary and integrative medicine. It may comprise both health professionals
172
and health associate professionals including, but not limited to, traditional,
173
complementary and integrative medicine professionals and associate professionals
174
(14).
175
Traditional and complementary medicine – merges the terms “traditional medicine”
176
and “complementary medicine” (15).
177
Traditional knowledge – there is no internationally accepted definition, but it can be
178
considered as knowledge, know-how, skills and practices that are developed,
179
sustained and passed on from generation to generation within a community, often
180
forming part of its cultural or spiritual identity (16).

1. INTRODUCTION
224
1.1 Traditional, complementary and integrative medicine
225
Traditional medicine (TM) is present across all six regions of the World Health
226
Organization (WHO) in both codified and non-codified systems and is profoundly
227
rooted in its traditional medical knowledge (TMK), culture, history and territories. TM
228
that has been adopted and adapted to the local context is referred to as
229
“complementary medicine”. The terms “traditional medicine” and “complementary
230
medicine” are considered as interchangeable.
231
The WHO traditional medicine strategy: 2014-2023 (15) provided the context of
232
traditional and complementary medicine (T&CM) - a merger of the terms “traditional
233
medicine” and “complementary medicine”.
234
As people become more empowered to choose the right health care for their needs,
235
health services today have to meet this challenge and offer a people-centred approach.
236
The practice of integrative medicine (IM), whether government-led or patient-led, that
237
combines proven TM and biomedicine will become more common.
238
In 2017, WHO effectively expanded its mandate for the much-needed support of
239
Member States in the developing field of IM and introduced the concept of “traditional,
240
complementary and integrative medicine” (TCIM).
241
This strategy therefore provides an expanded vision comprising TM, T&CM and TCIM.
242
This latter term brings together these three approaches, which are appropriately based
243
on individual health needs.
244
1.2 WHO mandate and support of TCIM
245
In 2014, the Sixty-seventh World Health Assembly (WHA) adopted the resolution
246
WHA67.18 on TM, which requested the Director-General to facilitate Member States’
247
implementation of the WHO traditional medicine strategy: 2014–2023. WHO has
248
continuously supported TM, T&CM and TCIM in implementing TM strategies according
249
to the mandate of the WHA.
250
Following the Seventy-sixth WHA decision, WHA76(20), to develop a new global TM
251
strategy for the period 2025–2034, WHO conducted the third WHO global survey on
252
TCIM to provide opportunities for Member States to review and provide input on
253
governance, financing, physical infrastructure, health workforce, products, information
254
and research, models of care, quality, access and availability, service coverage, and
255
responsiveness, including Member States’ challenges and needs related to TCIM.
256
Member States have requested technical and policy guidance from WHO to help
257
address the following challenges (20) (21):
258
•
the need for research data and financial support for research;
259
•
the need for mechanisms to regulate, control and monitor the quality of T&CM
260
practitioners and the safety, quality and effectiveness of T&CM practices and
261
products; and
262
•
the need for expertise, cooperation channels and information-sharing mechanisms
263
to help inform and bridge the gap due to the current lack of policy guidance on the
264
integration of T&CM into health systems and services.
265

266

267

268

269

270

271

273

2.4 Regulation of TCIM products and practices
325
Following the growing popularity of herbal medicines and other TCIM products, the
326
need of Member States for robust regulatory standards and requirements continues.
327
This includes the identification of critical norms and standards including reference to
328
national pharmacopoeia (Fig. 2.5) or monographs (Fig. 2.6) for herbal medicines to
329
ensure accurate information for consumers, high-quality products, and sustainable and
330
ethical practices for sourcing medicines. While adapting existing pharmaceutical
331
regulatory frameworks for TCIM products offer a starting point, it is crucial to develop
332
context-specific regulations, acknowledging the unique characteristics and practices of
333
diverse TCIM systems.
334
Where required, the appropriate regulation of TCIM practices is critical, balancing
335
concerns about restrictions with ensuring effectiveness. Education is key, but
336
standards may vary globally, although the inclusion of T&CM education at university
337
level has been rising (Fig. 2.7), while there is a significant introduction of continuing
338
professional development programmes (Fig. 2.8). Clear policy guidelines and
339
practitioner consultation are essential. Preserving traditional knowledge and
340
philosophies, while protecting them from inappropriate regulation is crucial, especially
341

3. VISION
368
Universal access to safe, effective, people-centred TCIM for the health and well-being
369
of all at all ages.
370
4. GOAL
371
To maximize the contribution of TCIM to the highest attainable standard of health and
372
well-being of individuals and societies, UHC and SDGs through cross-sectoral
373
approaches aimed at empowering communities by strengthening the evidence base,
374
and providing appropriate regulatory mechanisms and the integration of T&CM into
375
health services and systems.
376
5. GUIDING PRINCIPLES
377
The strategy was developed based on the following principles, which also guide the
378
implementation of actions by Member States, partners and stakeholders and WHO in
379
achieving its vision and goal.
380
5.1 Evidence-informed decision-making
381
Decisions should be informed by the best available evidence from research, as well as
382
by factors such as context, public opinion, equity, feasibility of implementation,
383
affordability, sustainability and acceptability to stakeholders (23). Decisions for the safe
384
and effective use of TCIM may be enhanced by appropriate robust research and use
385
of technology, which in turn furthers education and continuous learning.
386
5.2 Holism and health
387
TCIM encompasses various complete medical systems rooted in holistic perspectives,
388
emphasizing the interconnectedness of the human being not only within itself, but also
389
with the environment and the properties that arise from their interactions. These
390
systems, developed across diverse cultures and backgrounds, conceptualize health
391
as restoring and maintaining the balance and wholeness of individuals (24), thus
392
contributing to a positive vision of health that integrates physical, mental, spiritual and
393
social well-being.
394
5.3 Sustainability and One Health
395
Modern health care, including TCIM, should prioritize therapeutic interventions that
396
consciously support environmental sustainability. In general, TCIM is rooted in natural
397
resources, traditional knowledge, culture and history and can contribute significantly
398
not only to safeguarding biodiversity by promoting sustainable practices, but also to
399
achieving the SDGs related to health and well-being and to the One Health concept.
400
5.4 The right to health and patient autonomy
401
The WHO Constitution asserts health as a fundamental human right, emphasizing
402
universal access to needed health services without financial hardship. The right to
403
autonomy in health decisions necessitates support for informed choices.
404
5.5 Culture and health
405
Interculturalism is essential for the acceptability of health care. Recognizing the
406
importance of aligning health care needs and the preferences, lifestyles and cultural
407

5.6 Person-centred care and community engagement
411
Person-centred care and community engagement are key priorities in the delivery of
412

413

414

416
5.7 Integrated health care services and user benefit and safety
417
For optimal outcomes, health services should be coordinated seamlessly across
418
different medical disciplines and should prioritize individual well-being while
419
safeguarding against unsafe practices, false claims and unethical practices. Integrating
420
safe, effective, and sustainable T&CM can contribute to an approach which
421

The knowledge, attributes and value of TCIM offer the potential to cope with challenges

431

432
range of knowledge and procedures, such as medicines, foods, procedure-based
433
interventions, manual therapies and spiritual healing practices. Policies and
434
approaches for the appropriate use of TCIM include capitalizing on its potential in
435
health services and self-care, both of which are critical in primary health care.
436
Indigenous TMK holds essential wisdom, which is vital for Indigenous Peoples, and
437

438

443
